linkTarget.anchoringText: The Central North Sea is a Jurassic rift basin and one of Europe's most important oil and gas basins. The principal areas of activity in the basin are the Central Graben with extensions into the Moray Firth and the Viking Graben (see Figure 1). Exploration targets are mainly the sandstone reservoirs in the Upper Jurassic Fulmar and Palaeocene Forties formations as well as the chalk reservoirs of the Danian Ekofisk Formation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Section map of the North Sea showing the key structural elements as Central Graben, Viking Graben and Moray Firth (modified from Robertson et al., 2013).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Section map of the North Sea showing the key structural elements as Central Graben, Viking Graben and Moray Firth (modified from Robertson et al., 2013 ).

linkTarget.bib:
Robertson et al., 2013
J Robertson . N.R Goulty . & R.E Swarbrick .2013. Overpressure distributions in Palaeogene reservoirs of the UK Central North Sea and implications for lateral and vertical fluid flow. Petroleum Geoscience, Online First, 15 p..

linkTarget.anchoringText: The complex geological history of the basin as detailed in Underhill and Partington (1993) and Primio and Neumann (2008) is dominated by extensional tectonics, thermal doming, rifting and subsidence. As shown in Figure 2, the known stratigraphy comprises several rock types that are dominated by mudstones, chalk and sandstones of a range of ages from the pre-Permian to Recent.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Simplified regional stratigraphy of the Central North Sea showing dominant lithotypes in the stratigraphic intervals (source: Winefield et al., 2005). The presence of mature source rocks and competent reservoirs adds significantly to the economic value of the basin.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simplified regional stratigraphy of the Central North Sea showing dominant lithotypes in the stratigraphic intervals (source: Winefield et al., 2005 ). The presence of mature source rocks and competent reservoirs adds significantly to the economic value of the basin.

linkTarget.bib:
Winefield et al., 2005
P Winefield . R Gilham . and R Elsinger ., 2005. Plumbing the depths of Central Graben: towards an integrated pressure,fluid and charge model for the Central North Sea HPHT play. In: Dore, A.G. And Vining, B.A. (eds) Petroleum Geology: North-West Europe and Global Perspectives ï¿½ Proceedings of the 6th Petroleum Geology Conference, 1301 1315 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Included in this study are wells from the West Central Shelf (21/17-3, 21/19-2, 21/25-2, 29/7-1, 30/12b-2), northern West Central Graben (21/20a-1, 22/21-4, 22/21-7, 22/27a-1), Fisher Bank Basin (22/2-2), southern West Central Graben (29/4a-2, 29/5a-1, 29/5a-3, 29/9c-4, 29/10-2) and Mid Graben (22/28a-1, 22/30a-1, 29/5b-4) areas. The distribution of the wells is shown in Figure 3 on a Base Cretaceous map of the Central Graben, highlighting the good spread of data and distinct structural areas of the basin covered by the data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Spatial distribution of study wells on a Base Cretaceous depth surface map of the Central North Sea. Wells were chosen to reflect the key areas of the graben: West Central Shelf, northern and southern West Central Graben, Fisher Bank Basin and Mid Graben. Note the depth contrast between the graben margins and the inner graben. The West Central Shelf could be as shallow as 300 m, while the Mid Graben areas could be deeper than 6600 m.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spatial distribution of study wells on a Base Cretaceous depth surface map of the Central North Sea. Wells were chosen to reflect the key areas of the graben: West Central Shelf, northern and southern West Central Graben, Fisher Bank Basin and Mid Graben. Note the depth contrast between the graben margins and the inner graben. The West Central Shelf could be as shallow as 300 m, while the Mid Graben areas could be deeper than 6600 m.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results of overpressure estimation using the two chosen methods (Eaton, 1975; Yang and Aplin, 2004) in the identified mudstone intervals and their relationship with measured data and drilling mud weights in each of the wells are shown in Figure 4. For each of the wells discussed, the NCT and VES compaction models that are representative of the location of the wells in the basin as described in Nwozor (2016) were respectively applied.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Level of success of standard pore pressure prediction across the major areas of the graben. Log-based estimates are consistent with reservoir data only in the Cenozoic section, but underestimates sub-Chalk reservoir overpressure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Level of success of standard pore pressure prediction across the major areas of the graben. Log-based estimates are consistent with reservoir data only in the Cenozoic section, but underestimates sub-Chalk reservoir overpressure.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fisher Bank Basin and mid Graben as the main areas of challenge. While it is often suggested that adjusting Eaton exponents to higher values will yield a match between log-based estimates and the observed overpressure in areas of suspected multiple overpressure mechanisms, however, the geological validity of changing the Eaton exponent in the context of pore pressure prediction and understanding the causes of overpressure is still diffuse. Thus, as subsequently shown in Figure 5, the results of changing the Eaton exponent to fit local observations indicate that improved fits could always be achieved, but a wide range of Eaton exponents that exceed 4.0 in many cases are required in the Central North Sea (see Table 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Examples of the effect of adjusting Eaton exponent values to fit estimated overpressure with measured data in the reservoir. Green trend is the overpressure profile from the Eaton exponent of 2.5 (default value established for sub-Chalk in this study) while the new profile from the adjusted Eaton exponent is in blue.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Examples of the effect of adjusting Eaton exponent values to fit estimated overpressure with measured data in the reservoir. Green trend is the overpressure profile from the Eaton exponent of 2.5 (default value established for sub-Chalk in this study) while the new profile from the adjusted Eaton exponent is in blue.

linkTarget.anchoringText: It is expected that higher Eaton exponents would correlate with higher overpressures so that a predictive strategy will be achieved. However, this is not the case. The lack of correlation between modified Eaton exponents and reservoir overpressures is made more obvious on a cross-plot of both quantities (Figure 6). Wells in the plot have been coloured according to their locations in the graben. Purple colour denotes wells in the West Central Shelf, green and blue for those in the northern and southern West Central Graben while the Fisher Bank and Mid Graben wells are coloured red.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Comparing modified Eaton exponents with amounts of overpressure shows no clear pattern of data distribution. An exponent of 2.5 fits data only in the West Central Shelf wells (purple coloured data) where overpressure is typically low and expected to be caused by disequilibrium compaction. Across the rest of the study area, the wells bear no identical Eaton exponent.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparing modified Eaton exponents with amounts of overpressure shows no clear pattern of data distribution. An exponent of 2.5 fits data only in the West Central Shelf wells (purple coloured data) where overpressure is typically low and expected to be caused by disequilibrium compaction. Across the rest of the study area, the wells bear no identical Eaton exponent.
